titleStmt.title: Dean Swifts translation of a Latin inscription
written by dean Smedly, (& engravd under his

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: The very revrend Dean Smedly,
Of Dulness, Pride, conceit, a medly,
Was equally allowd to shine,
As poet, scholar, & divine.
With godliness could well dispence,
Would be a rake, but wanted sense.
Would strictly after Truth enquire,
Because he dreaded to come nigh her.
For liberty no champion bolder,
He hated balifs at his shoulder,
To half the world a standing jest,
A perfect nuisance to the rest.
For many, (& we may believe him)
Had the best wishes they could give him.
To all mankind a constant friend.
Provided they had cash to lend.
One thing he did before he went hence
He left us a laconic sentence,
But cutting of his phrase, & trimming,
To prove that bishops were old women.
Poor Envy durst not shew his phiz,
She was so terrified at his.
He waded without any shame,
Through thick & thin, to get a name.
Tried every sharping trick for bread,
And after all he seldom sped.
When Fortune favourd he was nice,
He never once would cog the dice:
But, as she turnd against his play,
He knew to stop a quartre trois.
Now sound in mind, & sound in corpus,
(Says he) though swelld like any porpus.
Hey heys from hence at forty-four,
(But by his leave he sinks a score),
To the East Indies, there to cheat,
Till he can purchase an estate;
Where, after he had filld his chest,
Hell mount his tub, & preach his best,
And plainly proves, by dint of text,
This world is his, & theirs the next.
Lest that the reader should not know,
The bank where last he set his toe,
'Twas Greenwich, There he took a ship,
And gave his creditors the slip.
In seventeen hundred eight & twenty,
To Fort StÌ£ George a pedlar wen he,
Ye Fates, when all he gets is spent,
Returns him beggar as he went!455-083Y
